newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Kokumin Bank to issue new shares.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Kokumin Bank to issue new shares.

text.p: The Kokumin Bank Ltd, a Tokyo-based second-tier regional bank, said on Tuesday that it would issue new shares worth 16.9 billion yen to its major shareholder Kokusai Kogyo Co Ltd in March, 1997, to help write off its problem loans.

A bank official said that the bank plans to dispose of 22.2 billion yen of problem loans in fiscal 1996/97 to next March, which will result in a parent current loss of 15.4 billion yen and a net loss of 12.9 billion yen.
In order to make up for the net losses, it will increase capital through the third-party new share issues, he said.
Kokumin Bank, whose shares are unlisted, was 63.01 percent owned by Kokusai Kogyo as of the end of March, 1996, the bank official said.
Assets held by the bank totalled 693.4 billion yen at the end of March.
Following the capital increase, the bank's capital ratio would rise to 4.37 percent at the end of March, 1997 from 3.85 percent a year ago, he said.
